description: Concerning fee disclosure for lodging accommodations.

original.text:
H-0212.1
HOUSE BILL 1080
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByRepresentatives Donaghy, Ryu, Ramel, Morgan, Fosse, Pollet, Kloba, Berg, Ormsby, Reeves, and Hill
Prefiled 12/16/24.Read first time 01/13/25.Referred to Committee on Consumer Protection & Business.
AN ACT Relating to fee disclosure for lodging accommodations; adding a new section to chapter 19.48 RCW; adding a new section to chapter 64.37 RCW; prescribing penalties; providing an effective date; and declaring an emergency.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 1. A new section is added to chapter 19.48 RCW to read as follows:
(1) All fees or charges required to stay at a hotel must be disclosed in the advertised, displayed, or offered room rate, except for taxes and fees imposed by a government.
(2) A hotel shall include in the total price to be paid, before the consumer reserves the stay, all taxes and fees imposed by a government.
(3) This section applies to any advertising, display, or offer that is before the public in this state, or from this state before the public in any state.
(4)(a) A person that knew or should have known that he or she has advertised, displayed, or offered a room rate in violation of this section is subject to a civil penalty not exceeding $10,000 for each violation.
(b) An action to enforce this section may be brought by a city attorney, county prosecuting attorney, or the attorney general.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 2. A new section is added to chapter 64.37 RCW to read as follows:
(1) All fees or charges required to stay at a short-term rental must be disclosed in the advertised, displayed, or offered rate, except for taxes and fees imposed by a government.
(2) Before a guest reserves a stay at a short-term rental, all taxes and fees imposed by a government must be included in the total price to be paid.
(3) This section applies to any advertising, display, or offer that is before the public in this state, or from this state before the public in any state.
(4)(a) A person that knew or should have known that he or she has advertised, displayed, or offered a room rate in violation of this section is subject to a civil penalty not exceeding $10,000 for each violation.
(b) An action to enforce this section may be brought by a city attorney, county prosecuting attorney, or the attorney general.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 3. This act is necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health, or safety, or support of the state government and its existing public institutions, and takes effect July 1, 2025.
--- END ---

summary.text:
Purpose

The purpose of House Bill 1080 is to enhance fee disclosure for lodging accommodations, ensuring that consumers are fully informed of all charges associated with their stay at hotels and short-term rentals. The key change in this bill is the requirement that all fees or charges, except for government-imposed taxes and fees, must be included in the advertised room rate. This aims to prevent hidden fees that can surprise consumers at the time of booking. The bill also sets penalties for non-compliance to promote adherence to these disclosure requirements.

Key Provisions

Hotel Fees Disclosure

  • All fees or charges required to stay at a hotel must be included in the advertised room rate.
  • Government-imposed taxes and fees must be disclosed in the total price before a consumer reserves the stay.
  • This requirement applies to advertisements and offers made in or from Washington state.
  • Violators, who should have known about the misleading advertisement, may face civil penalties up to $10,000 for each infraction. Enforcement actions may be initiated by local attorneys or the attorney general.

Short-Term Rental Fees Disclosure

  • Similar to hotel requirements, all fees for short-term rentals must be clearly displayed in the offered rate.
  • Government-imposed taxes and fees must also be included in the total price prior to booking.
  • This provision similarly applies to all forms of advertising and offers in and from Washington state.
  • Penalties for violations match those outlined for hotels, with the possibility of civil fines up to $10,000 and enforcement by legal authorities.

Effective Date

  • The act is set to take effect on July 1, 2025, as it is deemed necessary for the preservation of public peace, health, or safety.

summary.text:
Purpose

The main goal of the edits to the proposed legislature bill is to clarify the requirements for fee disclosure related to hotel and short-term rental accommodations. The revised version expands the types of fees that must be included in the advertised rates, specifically mentioning fees associated with government-created special districts or programs. This change aims to ensure greater transparency for consumers when reserving accommodations, allowing them to have a clearer understanding of total costs before making a reservation.

Key Changes

Changes in Fee Disclosure Requirements

  • The definition of fees that must be disclosed has been broadened to include:
    • Assessment fees of a government-created special district or program.

Clarification on Total Price Inclusion

  • The revised bill now specifies that both:
    • All taxes and government-imposed fees.
    • Assessment fees of a government-created special district or program must be included in the total price before the consumer reserves a stay.

These changes enhance the original bill by ensuring that consumers are better informed about the total costs associated with their stays, thereby promoting fairness in pricing practices.
